questions.text: Some new vaccines are being studied in the market and their efficacies are compared and presented as shown below. Which newer vaccine has same efficacy as compared to the previous vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C, D, E Options A, C and D are false. Vaccines C, D and E can be used with the same efficacy as compared to the previous vaccine.

Highyeild:

Equivalence study is carried out with the aim of showing there are no significant differences in the efficacy between the new drug and the standard drug. To conclude the equivalence, the whisker (tail) of the box whisker plot must lie within the zone of equivalence.

questions.text: 4 groups of homogenous samples were taken. The height and weight of each group had a correlation coefficient of 0.6. The total correlation of the combined whole group will be?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Equal to 0.6 In a homogenous sample or population, the total coefficient of correlation (r) will be the average of the individual correlation coefficients.

Highyeild:

The correlation coefficient is a statistical measure of the strength of a linear relationship between two variables. Its values can range from -1 to 1. A correlation coefficient of -1 describes a perfect negative, or inverse, correlation, with values in one series rising as those in the other decline, and vice versa. A coefficient of 1 shows a perfect positive correlation, or a direct relationship. A correlation coefficient of 0 means there is no linear relationship.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true?

options.label: D
options.text: In low prevalence, positive result of a highly sensitive test means true positive.

questions.correct_answer: A. PPV increases with increasing prevalence
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PPV increases with increasing prevalence

Highyeild:

Positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that a patient with a positive test result has actually contracted the disease. PPV depends on prevalence of the disease. If the disease is more prevalent, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive (high PPV).

Random:

Explanation for incorret options: - Sensitivity and specificity are the characters of the test, it does not depend on prevalence of the disease. Option D – In low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test need not always mean true positive (high proportion of false positives will be produced).

questions.text: The graphical presentation for flow cytometry analysis is done by which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Histogram and dot plot Flow cytometry can be presented on histogram of dot plot.

Highyeild:

Histograms – These are one dimensional. These compare only a single parameter. A large number of events detected at one particular intensity will be displayed as a spike on the histogram. Eg: Dot plot - Dot plots can compare 2 or more parameters simultaneously on a 2 D scatterplot. Each distinct event is represented as a single dot and events with similar intensities will cluster together in the same region on the scatter plot. Eg.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: At a PHC 50 patients were transferred from another center and required antihypertensive treatment. 40 people were given amlodipine (5mg PO). 10 have contraindication to use of amlodipine so those were started with lisinopril (10mg PO). The drugs are supplied at the PHC on monthly basis. So, how many medications will you order extra with Reorder factor (rf) to maintain the stocks and provide health care to community?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1600, rf=2 In the given question, lead time (LT) and procurement period (PP) are 1 month each. Reorder factor = LT + PP = 1 + 1 = 2. Average consumption in a month = (40 tablets of amlodipine + 10 tablets of lisinopril) x 30 days = 50 X 30 = 1500. Since the patients are transferred from another center and there is no safety stock for them at the present facility. In order to prevent stockouts, an extra number of tablets must be ordered. So, option D. 1600, rf = 2 is correct.

Highyeild:

Quantity to order = Average consumption per month X reorder factor. Reorder factor (rf) = Lead time + procurement period. Lead time : The time between initiation of purchase order and receipt at the warehouse from the supplier. Procurement period: Time until next regular order will be placed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: Which of the following is true for mobile medical units (MMU)?

options.label: B
options.text: MMU run by external agency with medical supplies given by the govt.

options.label: C
options.text: MMU run by government and medical supplies also by government.

options.label: D
options.text: MMU run by external agency and supplies also by external agency.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

MMU are government operated A, B, C are true (MMU are government operated / MMU run by external agency with medical supplies given by the govt. /MMU run by government and medical supplies also by government).

Highyeild:

Mobile medical units (MMU) is an initiative by NRHM to provide range of health care services for people living in remote, inaccessible, unserved and underserved areas in both rural as well as urban areas. MMUs can be run either by government or an external agency but the drugs and medical supplies are always provided by the government.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial screening test used to diagnose diabetes in a primary health center? Hba1c > 6.5 Random blood sugar> 200mg/dl Fasting blood sugar > 125 mg/dl 2-hour post-glucose load blood sugar> 200mg/dl Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C and D

Highyeild:

Fasting blood glucose (FBS) and Blood sugar after 2 hrs of glucose load (oral glucose tolerance test) are used for screening of Diabetes. In India, facility for HbA1c estimation is usually available only at tertiary centers.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.

questions.text: Which of the following will be discarded in the black bag?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gloves paper covering As it comes under general solid waste.

Highyeild:

Black bin is used to collect general solid waste like food waste, paper waste and mineral water bottles. So the glove cover should be discarded in black bins.

Random:

Explanation for incorret options: - Contaminated linen should be discarded in yellow bin. Gloves and contaminated gloves should be discarded in red bins (solid recyclable waste).

questions.text: Which of the following supplement nutrient is required in higher doses as per recommendations for daily allowance for lactating female compared to pregnant female?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Calcium RDA of calcium for lactating female is 1200mg/day and for pregnant female is 1000mg/day.

Highyeild:

RDA updates – 2020, by NIN Variable Non pregnant Pregnancy Lactation Body weight 55kg 55kg + 10kg in entire pregnancy Energy (kcal/day) Sedentary – 1660 Moderate – 2130 Heavy - 2720 +350 0 – 6 m -> + 600 6 – 12 m -> + 520 Protein (g/d) 45.7 1 st trim. – 45.7g 2 nd trim. - +9.5g 3 rd trim. - + 22g 0 – 6m -> +16.9g 6 – 12m -> + 13.2g Carbohydrates (g/d) 130 175 200 Iron (mg/d) 29 40 23 Iodine (mcg/d) 150 250 280 Calcium (mg/d) 1000 1000 1200 Vitamin A (mcg/d) 840 900 950 Folate (mcg/d) 220 570 330

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false. RDA of vitamin A is also high in lactation compared to pregnancy but it is met by diet, not given as supplement nutrition.

questions.text: Point C in the following diagram represents:

options.label: A
options.text: Onset of clinical signs and symptoms

questions.correct_answer: A. Onset of clinical signs and symptoms
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Onset of clinical signs and symptoms The given diagram shows natural history of disease and the point ‘c' represents onset of symptoms.

Highyeild:

Point A – exposure Point B – Stage of subclinical disease Point C – Onset of symptoms Point D – Usual time of diagnosis. Lead time – It is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.
